hints_raw:
Without doing any calculations, where is the centre of the unit disc, <math>\{(x,y)\,|\,x^{2} + y^{2} \le 1\}</math>? What is the discs' area?
Try making a change of coordinates to simplify the evaluation of the integrals that will show up. Don't forget the <b>Jacobian</b>.
sols_html:
Since D is the unit disc, we know that it is a circle of radius 1 and so it has area \(\pi\), i.e.

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle A(D) = \pi\end{aligned}\]

The centre of D is the origin and so (a,b) = (0,0). To evaluate the integral,

\[\begin{aligned} \iint_{D} \sqrt{(x - 0)^{2} + (y - 0)^{2}}\,dx\,dy = \iint_{D} \sqrt{x^{2} + y^{2}}\,dx\,dy\end{aligned}\]

we use polar coordinates:

\[\begin{aligned} \iint_{D} \sqrt{x^{2} + y^{2}}\,dx\,dy = \int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_{0}^{1} r^{2}\,dr\,d\theta\end{aligned}\]

where we have used the fact that \(dx\,dy = r\,dr\,d\theta\) (i.e. the Jacobian of the transformation from Cartesian to Polar coordinates) and \(\sqrt{x^{2} + y^{2}} = r\). Evaluating the integral gives:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{0}^{2\pi}\int_{0}^{1} r^{2}\,dr\,d\theta = 2\pi \int_{0}^{1}r^{2}\,dr = \frac{2\pi}{3}.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, the average distance from any point within D and the centre of D (the origin) is \({\color{blue}\frac{1}{A(D)}\iint_{D} \sqrt{x^{2} + y^{2}}\,dx\,dy = \frac{2}{3}.}\)

statement_html:
The average distance of a point in the plane region D to a point (a,b) is defined by

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{A(D)}\iint\limits_D\sqrt{(x-a)^2+(y-b)^2}\textrm{d}x\textrm{d}y\end{aligned}\]

where A(D) is the area of the plane region D. Let D be the unit disk

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}1\geq{}x^2+y^2.\end{aligned}\]

Find the average distance of a point in D to the centre of D.
